profiles.name: Jane Eyre
clues: Published during the Victorian era under a male pseudonym
The protagonist works as a governess for a mysterious employer
Features a character with a hidden past locked away in an attic
Explores themes of independence and social class in 19th century England
Written by a British author from the Brontë family
The main character experiences a significant fire that changes her fate
Contains a romantic relationship between the governess and employer
The narrative is told from the protagonist's perspective
Set partially in a mansion called Thornfield Hall
Features a love triangle with St. John Rivers
The heroine refuses to compromise her principles for love
Contains supernatural elements including mysterious laughter
The title character's first name becomes her identity throughout the story
Published in 1847 as a novel
Influenced many feminist literary works that followed
The protagonist is orphaned and mistreated in her youth
Features gothic atmosphere and dark secrets
The story explores what equality means in marriage
A classic of English literature still widely taught in schools
The ending suggests hope and equality for the main character

profiles.name: The Great Gatsby
clues: Set during the Jazz Age in 1920s New York
Features a narrator who moves to Long Island
The protagonist is a self-made millionaire with mysterious wealth
Explores themes of wealth, love, and the American Dream
Contains lavish parties in a mansion
The main character fell in love with a woman from his past
Green light symbolizes the protagonist's desire and longing
Written by an American author known for depicting excess
The love interest is married to a wealthy but brutal man
Set in fictional towns based on Long Island
The story ends tragically with the protagonist's death
Features East Egg and West Egg as contrasting settings
The narrator is a bond salesman
Published in 1925
Contains a doctor as one of the main characters
The protagonist's real name is not Gatsby
Explores the corruption of the American Dream
Features a yellow car that becomes symbolically important
The woman at the center of the story is careless with her power
Considered one of the greatest American novels ever written

profiles.name: Jack Torrance
clues: Character from a horror novel by Stephen King
Works as a winter caretaker in an isolated setting
Struggles with alcoholism throughout his life
Possesses a supernatural ability called the shining
His violent outbursts are influenced by his surroundings
Wife is named Wendy
Has a young son with similar psychic abilities
Gradually loses his sanity due to isolation and supernatural forces
The setting includes a hedge maze
Features a famous typewriter in the narrative
His descent into madness is both psychological and supernatural
Becomes increasingly dangerous as the story progresses
The spirits of the location manipulate his thoughts
He is portrayed as complex rather than purely evil
His story explores themes of addiction and domestic violence
The character's past includes traumatic childhood experiences
He attempts to harm his family members
The story is set during winter with no escape possible
His transformation is gradual and horrifying
The novel examines how environments can corrupt the human soul

profiles.name: Pride and Prejudice
clues: Written by a British female author in the early 19th century
The story begins with a famous opening line about marriage
Features a protagonist who judges others too quickly
Set in Regency England with strict social hierarchies
The main character is named Elizabeth
Contains a proud and wealthy male character named Fitzwilliam
Features first proposals that are rejected
The story involves five sisters seeking advantageous marriages
Contains misunderstandings that drive the plot forward
The protagonist initially despises the male lead
Explores class differences and social expectations
Features letters that reveal important information
The main couple eventually sees past their initial impressions
Published in 1813
Contains themes of personal growth and self-awareness
Features visits to grand estates like Pemberley
The protagonist is headstrong and independent for her time
Contains comic relief through family members
The story emphasizes finding love based on genuine connection
Remains one of the most beloved romance novels in English literature

profiles.name: One Hundred Years of Solitude
clues: Magical realism novel by a Colombian author
Set in the fictional town of Macondo
Features multiple generations of the same family
Characters often have the same names, creating cyclical patterns
Blends fantastical elements with realistic narrative
The town experiences various transformations throughout history
A woman ascends to heaven while folding laundry
Features an old gypsy who returns with magical discoveries
The narrative covers approximately 100 years of family history
Contains biblical and mythological references
A plague of insomnia affects the entire town
The story uses non-linear storytelling techniques
Published in 1967 and became an international bestseller
The narrative is told from a detached, all-knowing perspective
Features incest as a recurring theme within the family
The town is isolated from the outside world
A final manuscript reveals the story's conclusion
The novel influenced countless writers and defined a genre
Contains elements of solitude and isolation as central themes
Considered one of the greatest novels of the 20th century

profiles.name: To Kill a Mockingbird
clues: Set in a fictional Alabama town during the Great Depression
Told through the eyes of a young girl named Scout
Features a lawyer father defending a wrongly accused Black man
Explores themes of racial injustice and moral courage
Contains childhood memories and coming-of-age elements
Features the character Atticus Finch as the moral compass
Set in a town called Maycomb
The trial is the central dramatic event of the story
Contains a mysterious neighbor who helps the children
Addresses prejudice and social inequality
The title refers to the innocence of those who can do no harm
Published in 1960 and won the Pulitzer Prize
Features a reclusive character named Boo Radley
The narrative jumps between present and past
Explores the loss of innocence and moral awakening
The children learn important life lessons through observation
Features a town that is divided by race and class
The story emphasizes standing up for what is right
Remains one of the most widely taught novels in American schools
Influenced discussions of race and morality in literature

profiles.name: The Catcher in the Rye
clues: Narrated by a teenage protagonist named Holden Caulfield
Set in New York City over a few days
Explores themes of alienation and teenage angst
The protagonist is cynical about the adult world he calls phony
Published in 1951 and became a controversial bestseller
Features stream-of-consciousness narrative style
The main character is recently expelled from school
Contains frequent use of profanity unusual for its era
The title refers to the protagonist's fantasy about saving children
Explores mental health struggles of a troubled young man
Set mostly in hotels and on city streets
Features the protagonist's interactions with various people
Contains reflections on loss of innocence
The narrative reveals the character's internal struggles
Addresses themes of depression and disconnection
The protagonist seeks authentic human connection
Features a red hunting hat as a symbolic object
Explores the protagonist's relationship with his younger sister
The ending suggests some hope for recovery and healing
Influenced generations of readers and remains culturally significant
Dystopian novel by George Orwell
Set in a totalitarian state called Oceania
Features a protagonist named Winston Smith
The government watches citizens through telescreens
The ruling party manipulates language to control thought
Explores themes of power, control, and surveillance
Published in 1949
Features the infamous concept of Big Brother
The narrative describes the protagonist's rebellion against the state
Contains the phrase doublethink to describe contradictory beliefs
Features the Ministry of Truth as an ironic institution
The protagonist falls in love with a woman named Julia
Explores psychological manipulation and torture
The story ends with the protagonist's defeat and submission
Serves as a warning about totalitarianism
Influenced political discourse and the term Orwellian
The narrative is dense with social commentary
Features propaganda and false history as tools of control
The novel remains relevant to discussions of government power
Considered a masterpiece of political fiction

The protagonist struggles to return home to Ithaca

Odysseus's wife Penelope waits faithfully at home
The journey takes approximately ten years
Contains encounters with the Cyclops and other monsters

The protagonist visits the underworld to consult the dead
Contains themes of heroism, perseverance, and redemption

The narrative is told through multiple perspectives

Contains the famous encounter with Sirens
The story emphasizes the hero's intelligence and cunning
Published in the ancient Greek period
Remains a foundational work of Western literature
Influenced countless writers and storytellers
The work has been translated and adapted many times

The story spans two generations of characters

The hero discovers he is braver than he initially believed

The story emphasizes the importance of friendship
Contains detailed descriptions of landscape and culture
The protagonist learns valuable lessons about the world

The work is considered a masterpiece of science fiction

profiles.name: Jane Austen
clues: British author who lived from 1775 to 1817

Her works focus on marriage and social relationships
Published six major novels during her lifetime
First published anonymously under the pseudonym A Lady
Her works explore the position of women in society

Her novels emphasize finding love based on understanding
Influenced the development of the modern novel
Her works satirize social conventions and expectations
Used irony and humor throughout her writing
Her novels are set in English country estates

Her works were not widely recognized until after her death
Influenced numerous writers and adaptations
Her novels remain bestsellers in modern times
Her works are frequently adapted for film and television
Considered one of the greatest authors in English literature

profiles.name: Slaughterhouse-Five

The protagonist Billy Pilgrim becomes unstuck in time

The narrative includes Billy's experiences in a POW camp
Features the bombing of Dresden as a central event
Billy is transported by aliens to the planet Tralfamadore
The Tralfamadorians view time all at once
Contains the phrase So it goes repeated throughout
Features themes of fate and free will
The novel is both humorous and tragic
Contains anti-war sentiment and criticism
The narrative structure mirrors Billy's fractured perception
Features Vonnegut's characteristic dark humor
Explores themes of death and meaning
Contains elements of science fiction
The protagonist represents many traumatized veterans
Explores the absurdity of war
Remains a powerful anti-war statement
Influenced discussions of war literature

profiles.name: Waiting for Godot

Features two main characters waiting for someone named Godot

The characters discuss whether Godot will come
Features secondary characters including Pozzo and Lucky
The play is divided into two acts with parallel action
Contains existential themes about purpose
The dialogue often consists of non-sequiturs
The play influenced modern drama profoundly
Features themes of hope and despair
Contains minimal action but rich themes
The ending mirrors the beginning
Written originally in French as En attendant Godot
Caused controversy and puzzlement upon premiere
Remains frequently performed and studied
Inspired countless interpretations and analyses
